utterances: Sure.

Yeah, one of the comments I think that hasn't really been touched upon is the fact that I think that as a young Cuban-American, I've been in this country since - I was born in this country, I should say - and I'm in my mid-40s.
And what I found is that people of Cuban background - depending on their socio-economic level within our community - have different opinions about how they would like to go back or not go back.

And I find that those that have not been as successful in this country tend to have more of a feeling of wanting to return than those that I think have been let's say more successful or of a higher socio-economic level.
Professor Garcia, we've talked about generational differences.
How much about this is differences in class?
I think the caller's absolutely correct.
I'm often asked who's likely to return to Cuba, you know, assuming that the Cuban state allows Cuban-Americans to return.
And that's a big if.
I think those - the more recent arrivals are probably among the more likely to return - those who feel disaffected, who never quite adapted to U.S.
society for whatever reason, either because they didn't learn the language or, you know, weren't able to earn a livelihood that was to their satisfaction.
There were anti-government demonstrations today in Morocco and news of increasing violence in Libya.
We'll have the latest.
But first, the number of Americans who own their own home is falling.
During the tour, Debosier gets a call on her cell phone from one of the loggers.
The disaffected, I think, would be more likely to return.
What I do see happening - again and this is a big if, assuming that the Cuban state one day allows this to happen - I do see a lot of traveling back and forth across the Florida Straits.
You know, there's a long history, you know, of travel back and forth across the Florida Straits.
Long before Fidel took power, Cubans were living in the United States.
Americans were living in Cuba and traveling, you know, spending part of their lives in each other's country.
And I could see that happening again.
Cuba is very close to the state of Florida, 100 to 110 miles.

I could very easily see a scenario where, you know, Cuban-Americans live in south Florida, hop on a plane and go to Santiago de Cuba or Havana or any of a number of cities and you know, operate a business there and then come back home at the end of the day in much the same way that other Americans commute between Washington, D.C.
and Boston and New York.
You know, we could see a commuter society of sorts.
But again, all of this is dependent on whether the Cuban state allows this to happen.
And given the long history of conflict between exiles and people on the island, it might not be possible.
And that's where I think the new generation steps in on both sides of the Florida Straits.
I think this is where the new generation will be important.
Tony, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
Of course there are still Cubans coming to the U.S.
every year, many of them born under the Castro regime and who never knew anything else.
Oscar Corral is another reporter for the Miami Herald.
He covers the Cuban exile community for that newspaper.
He's also with us from the studios of WLRN in Miami.
Welcome to you as well.
Thank you, Neal.
How different are these recent immigrants from the earlier generations, both from 50 years ago and then from Mariel?
Well, the first wave of immigrants that came from Cuba suffered the brunt of the communist revolution.
They lost property.
They had homes and cars and all kinds of private property confiscated, and that's the rancor that they brought with them and what charged them politically.
They had their lives stripped from them by this revolution.
That's the way they feel about it.
This newer generation of immigrants was born and raised mostly under the Castro government, and they never went through that shock of losing everything that they worked for.
They never experienced owning anything in Cuba, because in Cuba it's illegal to own anything.
It's illegal to own property or cars or businesses.
So they never experienced that shock of having lost everything that they worked for.
They come here with a different attitude.
They are more apolitical.
They tend to view Cuba through a prism of economic - just economic longing.
They couldn't make a living for themselves in Cuba.
They've crossed the Florida Straits looking to make a living, looking to make enough money to send back to their families.
They have not gotten involved with the politics of exile.
We're going to have to take a short break.
And hold on, all three of you.
We'll be back to continue this conversation with Cuban-Americans.
Plus we'll hear from some Sunni Muslims in Iraq about why some Sunni Muslims in Iraq pretend to be Shia and how they're learning how to do it.
And plus your letters.
I'm Neal Conan.
We'll be back after the break.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington, and here are the headlines from some of the other stories we're following here today at NPR News.
Israel says it plans to withdraw from southern Lebanon in as little as seven to 10 days, and to hand over some of its forward positions to U.N.
troops within 48 hours.
The timetable reflects growing concerns that the longer they stay, the more Israeli forces will become easy targets for Hezbollah.
And London investigators say funds sent to charities - ostensibly to provide aid to victims of last year's devastating in Pakistan - were used instead to finance the London bomb plot.
You can hear details on those stories and of course much more later today on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Tomorrow on TALK OF THE NATION, how travelers and the travel industry are adjusting to new security restrictions.
So join us at this time tomorrow for that.
Right now we're talking with Cuban-Americans about their reaction to the possibility of political change in their homeland.

Our guests are Maria Cristina Garcia - a professor of history at Cornell University - and two reporters for the Miami Herald: Susan Anasagasti, a staff writer, and Oscar Corral, a reporter for the Miami Herald who covers the Cuban exile community.
And Oscar Corral, we just introduced you just before the break.

And I wanted to ask you more about this more recent - the differences between the more recent arrivals and the flow of people - I mean, we saw that big bulge during the boat lift - Mariel - but in fact there have been more people coming in the past few years than even arrived back in the ‘80s.
That's right, Neal.
It's been a steady flow of Cuban immigrants coming in to the Miami area and to the United States from Cuba.
Over the last five years or six years alone, we've seen about 130,000 Cuban immigrants arrive.
That is more than arrived during the entire Mariel boatlift.
So it's a steady stream of immigrants, in part fueled by a visa lottery that the United States has which provides 20,000 exit visas to Cubans every year - legally - to come to the United States.
So we are constantly being I guess refreshed or injected with new arrivals from Cuba who bring with them the attitudes of the moment that dominate the island.

And right now the immigrants that are coming here - I did a story a few weeks ago about the new arrivals - and right now what you're seeing is a group of people who are so tired and just sick of politics that they don't want to have anything to do with it.
They don't have to deal with the politics in Cuba, and they don't want to have anything to do with the politics in Miami.
They just want to live their lives.
They just want to work and send money home to their families.
Some of them don't necessarily hate the Cuban government.
Some of them do.
Some of them just - they don't want to know how the exiles here felt in the early waves.
Unidentified Woman #4: Qatar.
They just want to get on with their lives.
And that change in attitude over the years I think is a reflection of people being raised under the Cuban government and their system.

It's people who have never understood or been subjected to capitalism or any sense of democracy where speaking out could cost you your freedom - where being in a country where, you know, longing to make an extra buck on a street corner by selling some flowers or selling some sugar could land you in jail.
That's the system they were raised in.
Every block in Cuba has a snitch, essentially, for the Cuban government.
And people are concerned to express their true feelings in Cuba, and that translates into their experience in Miami.
Many of the people I interviewed for that story, many of the new arrivals didn't even want to talk about how they felt about the Cuban government.
It was still that fear that they carried with them from the island, and it's a fear that translates into just apathy and an apolitical attitude.
Susan Anasagasti, I wanted to ask you - do Cuban-Americans, I mean, are these distinctions instantly recognizable?
Can you tell immediately, more or less, when somebody came?

Well, it depends because, you know, certainly when news broke that Castro had transferred power to his brother Raul an the area that I was covering - sort of in Little Havana, Westchester - the younger Cuban-Americans there had been raised by parents who came, you know - who came to the United States.
They were the original wave of Cubans who came to the United States in the early ‘60s.
So there is a difference there.
So I would say that probably the majority of those feel differently than the ones Oscar speaks about.
No, I was talking about sort of social distinctions.
You know, do these groups interact?
Do they mingle?
Do they talk to each other?
Do they help each other out?
They definitely interact.
And they definitely mingle, but there is a difference.

There is a distinct difference between them, and it's probably because of the different life experiences that they've each had - raised differently and different times that they've, you know, came to the United States.
And even in the politics of it all, they may not agree with each other.
Let's talk with Pedro.
Pedro's calling us from Miami.
Yeah, hi.
Hi.
Well, my comment is that I belong to possibly the last generation that witnessed a pre-Castro Cuba.
I was 11 years old when I came here.
My parents brought me over with my brothers and sisters.
And I think the sense that our generation has is that we want to see our parents vindicated.
I mean, these are folks who led very decent lives in Cuba.
They didn't torture anybody.
They were not part of the Batista regime, but yet they suffered greatly.
And I'm not just talking about material loss, I'm talking about jail time, I'm talking about a family member killed by the government.

And my parents spent their whole lifetime working very actively to see a free Cuba, and I think the sense that we feel when we see the beginning of the end of the Castro regime is a sense of vindication.
It isn't a sense of revenge or desire to get properties back.
It is simply - it's a very simple wish to see the motherland of our parents and where we were born free once more.
You see, we obviously - Fidel Castro turned 80 just the other day.
He's obviously ill.
We may be seeing the beginning of the end of Castro.
Do you, Pedro, see the beginning of the end of the Castro regime?
I do.
I don't see it immediately.
I don't believe that the physical passing away of Fidel will signify the end of his regime.
I think that their political machinery is very powerful, and it has tremendous control over the country.
But I think that change becomes inevitable because the internal contradictions of that system are massive.
I visited Cuba three years ago.
I went back after a lot of soul-searching.
And what I saw there was a wonderful, beautiful country with lovely, hospitable people run by an absolutely despicable regime.

And I think that once the people begin to understand that there's a little bit of wiggle room and they begin to see that there is a possibility of change, the floodgates will open and there will be a massive, popular demand for change.
Pedro, thanks very much for the phone call.
We appreciate it.
Thank you.
And we've heard a number of opinions.
I'm afraid we're going to have to end it there.
But I wanted to thank our guests.
Maria Cristina Garcia - a professor of history at Cornell University - joined us from the studios of that university in Ithaca, New York.
Appreciate your time today.
Thank you.
And two reporters for the Miami Herald: Susan Anasagasti is a staff writer and Oscar Corral a reporter for the Miami Herald.
And they joined us from the studios of our member station in Miami, WLRN.
Thanks for coming in.
